questions.text: The following CT scan image shows the types of the emphysema. Identify the paraseptal type of emphysema?
questions.solution:
Emphysema is characterized by destruction of gas-exchanging air spaces, i.e., the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and alveoli. Large numbers of macrophages accumulate in respiratory bronchioles of essentially all smokers. Neutrophils, B lymphocytes, and T lymphocytes, particularly CD8+ cells, are also increased in the alveolar space of smokers.

Alveolar walls become perforated and later obliterated with coalescence of the delicate alveolar structure into large emphysematous air spaces.

Emphysema is classified into distinct pathologic types, which include centrilobular, panlobular, and paraseptal.

Option C. Centrilobular emphysema, the type most frequently associated with cigarette smoking, is characterized by enlarged air spaces found (initially) in association with respiratory bronchioles. Centrilobular emphysema is usually most prominent in the upper lobes and superior segments of lower lobes and is often quite focal.

Option B. Panlobular emphysema refers to abnormally large air spaces evenly distributed within and across acinar units. Panlobular emphysema is commonly observed in patients with α1 AT deficiency, which has a predilection for the lower lobes.

Option A. Paraseptal emphysema occurs in 10-15% of cases and is distributed along the pleural margins with relative sparing of the lung core or central regions. It is commonly associated with significant airway inflammation and with centrilobular emphysema.

Key Takeaway:

Paraseptal emphysema is identified by its distribution along pleural margins with relative sparing of the central lung regions. It is associated with significant airway inflammation and often coexists with centrilobular emphysema.

Tags:

Topic Name: COPD:Classification

Difficulty level: Good to know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number: 2182

questions.text: The below image is algorithm for approach to cardiac arrest due to VT or VF (shockable rhythm). Identify the drug highlighted with pink?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions with ventilation and defibrillation or cardioversion should be initiated as soon as possible. Defibrillation should be repeated with minimal interruption of chest compressions. Once an intravenous or intraosseous access is established, administration of epinephrine defibrillation and amiodarone and defibrillation are performed. Further therapy can be guided by possible causes as suggested by the initial or recurrent cardiac rhythm as shown.

Option A. Atropine is primarily used for bradycardia and is not indicated in the management of ventricular fibrillation (VF) or pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT).

Option B. Epinephrine is the drug of choice for VF or pulseless VT after CPR and defibrillation fail to restore circulation. It is administered at 1 mg IV/IO every 3-5 minutes during the resuscitation process.

Option C. Amiodarone is indicated for refractory VF or pulseless VT after multiple shocks and administration of epinephrine. It is used only if defibrillation and epinephrine fail.

Option D. Adenosine is used for the management of narrow complex supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and has no role in VF or pulseless VT.

Key Takeaway: In VF or pulseless VT, epinephrine is the first-line medication after defibrillation and CPR fail, followed by amiodarone for refractory cases.

Tags:

Topic Name: Cardiac arrest:Management

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 2262

questions.text: Which of the following is a major predisposing factor for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Image shows Osmotic demyelination syndrome. Axial T2-weighted magnetic resonance scan through the pons reveals a symmetric area of abnormal high signal intensity within the basis pontis (arrows).

  1. Rapid correction of hyponatremia
    • ODS, previously termed central pontine myelinolysis, is strongly associated with the rapid correction of hyponatremia, which leads to demyelination in the brainstem (especially the pons). Gradual correction is critical to prevent this condition.
  2. Chronic hypernatremia
    • Hypernatremia is not directly associated with osmotic demyelination syndrome, though hyperosmolar states can play a role. Rapid correction of hypernatremia, however, does not typically lead to ODS.
  3. Untreated severe hypothyroidism
    • Hypothyroidism may contribute to other neurological conditions but is not linked to osmotic demyelination syndrome.
  4. Ischemic stroke
    • While stroke can result in neurological symptoms and damage, it is unrelated to the pathogenesis of osmotic demyelination syndrome, which is caused by rapid shifts in serum osmolarity.

Key Takeaway:

Osmotic demyelination syndrome occurs due to rapid correction of severe hyponatremia or hyperosmolar states. Gradual sodium correction is essential to prevent this condition.

The pathology consists of demyelination without inflammation in the base of the pons, with relative sparing of axons and nerve cells. MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without quadriplegia. Occasional cases present with lesions outside of the brainstem

Therapy for the restoration of severe hyponatremia should aim for gradual correction, i.e., by ≤8 mmol/L (8 meq/L) within 24 h and 15 mmol/L (15 meq/L) within 48 h.

Tags:

Topic Name: Electrolyte disorders:Hyponatremia

Difficulty level: May know

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page Number 2273

choices.text: The diagnosis of the image is Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
The classic presentation is an acute nephritic picture with hematuria, pyuria, red blood cell casts, edema, hypertension, and oliguric renal failure
Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis due to pharyngitis develops 1-3 weeks after infection and 2-6 weeks after impetigo.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding the below image?
questions.solution:
The renal biopsy in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis demonstrates hypercellularity of mesangial and endothelial cells; glomerular infiltrates of polymorphonuclear leukocytes; granular subendothelial immune deposits of IgG, IgM, C3, C4, and C5-9; and subepithelial deposits (which appear as "humps")

Option C. PSGN is not treated with immunosuppressive therapy. Supportive care, including control of hypertension, management of fluid overload, and close monitoring, is the mainstay of treatment.

Option A. The image illustrates key pathological features of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, including subepithelial humps and mesangial proliferation.

Option B. The classic presentation is an acute nephritic picture with hematuria, pyuria, red blood cell casts, edema, hypertension, and oliguric renal failure. Acute nephritic syndrome is the hallmark clinical presentation of PSGN, often associated with systemic symptoms like headache and flank pain.

Option D. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis due to pharyngitis develops 1-3 weeks after infection and 2-6 weeks after impetigo. This timeline is characteristic of the disease, reflecting the delayed immune-mediated response to nephritogenic strains of streptococci.

Key takeaways:

Tags:

Topic Name: Kidney disease:Glomerular disease

Difficulty level: Good to know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 2337

choices.text: Casts formed by filtered monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains and Tamm-Horsfall protein in the distal tubule.
Crescent formation with fibrinoid necrosis in glomeruli.
Linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: A 68 year old male patient known case of multiple myeloma presented with Acute Kidney Injury. His renal biopsy shown below. Which of the following key features about AKI in Multiple myeloma is true?
questions.solution:
Histologic appearance of myeloma cast nephropathy. A hematoxylin eosin-stained kidney biopsy shows many atrophic tubules filled with eosinophilic Casts.

  1. Casts formed by filtered monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains and Tamm-Horsfall protein in the distal tubule.
    • Light chain cast nephropathy occurs due to the aggregation of monoclonal light chains (Bence-Jones proteins) with Tamm-Horsfall protein in the distal tubules. These casts cause tubular obstruction and incite an inflammatory response, as shown in the histologic image.
  2. Crescent formation with fibrinoid necrosis in glomeruli.
    • This feature is characteristic of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), not LCCN.
  3. Linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane.
    • Linear IgG deposition is a hallmark of Goodpasture's syndrome, unrelated to LCCN.
  4. Subepithelial "humps" composed of immune complexes.
    • Subepithelial humps are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, not in LCCN.

Key Takeaway

Light chain cast nephropathy is a renal complication of multiple myeloma, characterized by tubular obstruction from casts formed by monoclonal light chains and Tamm-Horsfall protein, leading to tubular damage and interstitial inflammation. Detection of Bence-Jones proteins and monoclonal gammopathy is essential for diagnosis.

Tags:

Topic Name: Kidney disease:Glomerular disease:Cast Nephropathy

Difficulty level: Good to know

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 2360

choices.text: A:Erosive esophagitis, B:Esophageal stricture with chronic erosive esophagitis, C:Barrett's esophagus, D:Esophageal adenocarcinoma with Barrett's esophagus
A:Erosive esophagitis, B:Esophageal stricture with chronic erosive esophagitis, C:Esophageal adenocarcinoma with Barrett's esophagus, D:Barrett's esophagus
A:Barrett's esophagus, B:Esophageal stricture with chronic erosive esophagitis, C:Erosive esophagitis, D:Esophageal adenocarcinoma with Barrett's esophagus
A:Esophageal stricture with chronic erosive esophagitis, B:Erosive esophagitis, C:Barrett's esophagus, D:Esophageal adenocarcinoma with Barrett's esophagus

questions.text: Identify the endoscopic picture A,B,C and D respectively.
questions.solution:
A: Erosive esophagitis

  • Visible as inflamed and eroded areas in the esophageal mucosa. It is a common result of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

B: Esophageal stricture with chronic erosive esophagitis

  • A narrowed esophageal lumen caused by chronic inflammation and scarring, frequently due to untreated GERD.

C: Barrett's esophagus

  • Identified by columnar epithelium replacing the normal squamous epithelium in the esophagus. This metaplasia is a precancerous lesion caused by chronic GERD.

D: Esophageal adenocarcinoma with Barrett's esophagus

  • A raised, irregular, and ulcerated mass indicating malignancy. It is often a complication of Barrett's esophagus.

Key Takeaway:

The sequence of pathology progresses from erosive esophagitis to Barrett's esophagus and potentially to esophageal adenocarcinoma if left untreated. Early diagnosis and management of GERD can prevent these complications.

Tags:

Topic Name: G.I.T:Disorders of esophagus

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 2430

questions.text: The gross pathological image shown is most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The image depicts a thickened bowel wall, areas of stenosis, and linear serpiginous ulcers along with a cobblestone appearance of the mucosa. These features are characteristic of Crohn's disease.

A. Ulcerative colitis

  • Ulcerative colitis presents with continuous mucosal inflammation without skip lesions, typically starting from the rectum and progressing proximally. Cobblestoning and transmural thickening are not features of ulcerative colitis.

B. Crohn's disease

  • Crohn's disease shows patchy inflammation (skip lesions), transmural thickening of the bowel wall, linear ulcers, and cobblestoning, as seen in the image.

C. Ischemic colitis

  • Ischemic colitis typically shows segmental areas of hemorrhagic necrosis and pale areas of ischemia, not the cobblestone-like appearance or transmural thickening seen here.

D. Colorectal carcinoma

  • Colorectal carcinoma presents as mass lesions or ulcerating tumors, not the diffuse thickening and cobblestoning of the mucosa evident in the image.

Key Takeaway

The hallmark features of Crohn's disease include skip lesions, transmural inflammation, linear ulcers, and cobblestoning, all of which are evident in the gross pathological image provided.

Tags:

Topic Name: G.I.T:Inflammatory bowel diseases

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 2474

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment option for the management of disease shown in below peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows sickle cells, which are characteristic of sickle cell anemia, a genetic disorder caused by the polymerization of hemoglobin S (HbS) under hypoxic conditions.

Option A. Voxelotor is a drug that increases the oxygen affinity of hemoglobin, thereby reducing HbS polymerization and subsequent sickling. It acts pancellularly, providing an additional protective mechanism across all erythrocytes.

  • In clinical studies, voxelotor improved hemoglobin levels (≥1 g/dL increase in 59% of patients) and reduced hemolysis markers, potentially reducing complications like stroke, nephropathy, and pulmonary hypertension.
  • It is commonly added to hydroxyurea therapy if hydroxyurea alone is insufficient.

Option B. Eculizumab is NOT discussed in the provided text. This monoclonal antibody targets complement component C5, inhibiting the terminal complement cascade. It is primarily used in conditions like:

  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).
  • Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS).
    It has no role in the pathophysiology of sickle cell anemia, as the disease is not complement-mediated

Option C. Hydroxyurea is the standard of care for all patients with sickle cell anemia, starting in the first year of life unless contraindicated.

  • Mechanism: It increases fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which inhibits HbS polymerization. This provides heterocellular protection, meaning not all red blood cells have equal benefit.
  • Outcomes: Reduces pain and acute chest syndrome by ~50%, increases hemoglobin levels by ~1 g/dL, and reduces long-term mortality by ~49%.

Option D. Crizanlizumab is a P-selectin inhibitor. By preventing the adhesion of sickled red cells to the endothelium, it reduces vaso-occlusive episodes.

  • Outcomes: Acute painful episodes are reduced by ~45%, similar to hydroxyurea. However, it does not affect hemolysis.
  • Use: It can be combined with hydroxyurea or voxelotor if vaso-occlusive crises persist despite optimized therapy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Voxelotor, hydroxyurea, and crizanlizumab are valid treatment options for sickle cell anemia.
  • Eculizumab, though a highly effective drug in complement-mediated disorders, has no role in sickle cell anemia.

Tags:

Topic Name: Hematology:Sickle cell disease

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 761

questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for the rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve?
questions.solution:
The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve describes the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) and hemoglobin's oxygen saturation. Factors that influence hemoglobin's oxygen affinity cause shifts in the curve, either enhancing or reducing oxygen delivery to tissues.

P50 Value:

  1. P50 is the partial pressure of oxygen at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated.
  2. Normal P50 is ~26 mmHg.
  3. High P50 (Right Shift): Indicates decreased oxygen affinity, meaning oxygen is released more easily to tissues.
  4. Low P50 (Left Shift): Indicates increased oxygen affinity, meaning oxygen is held more tightly by hemoglobin.

Tense (T) and Relaxed (R) States of Hemoglobin:

  1. T-State: Deoxyhemoglobin has a low affinity for oxygen.
  2. R-State: Oxyhemoglobin has a high affinity for oxygen.

Bohr Effect: Acidic conditions (low pH) enhance oxygen release by stabilizing the T-state. This shifts the curve to the right.

2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG): 2,3-BPG binds to hemoglobin and reduces its affinity for oxygen, favoring oxygen delivery to tissues. It stabilizes the T-state.

The question asks which factor is responsible for a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve.

Option A: Increased pH

  • Increased pH (alkalosis) causes a leftward shift, enhancing oxygen affinity and reducing delivery to tissues.

Option B: Increased 2,3-BPG

  • 2,3-BPG binds to deoxygenated hemoglobin and stabilizes the T-state, reducing oxygen affinity and promoting oxygen release to tissues.

Option C: Decreased Temperature

  • Decreased temperature shifts the curve left, increasing oxygen affinity.

Option D: Both A and C

  • Both increased pH and decreased temperature cause a leftward shift, not a rightward shift.

Key Takeaway

  • Rightward shift = Enhanced oxygen delivery to tissues.
  • Caused by increased 2,3-BPG, decreased pH (acidosis), increased temperature, and increased CO2.
  • Among the given options, increased 2,3-BPG is the correct answer.

Tags:

Topic Name: Hematology:Hemoglobin disorders

Difficulty level: Good to know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page Number 756

choices.text: Acute subdural hematoma following head trauma
Chronic subdural hematoma following head trauma
Acute epidural hematoma following head trauma

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic man presents to the emergency department with a history of head trauma sustained during a motor vehicle accident today morning. A noncontrast CT scan brain given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C.The condition is acute epidural hematoma (EDH), which is a collection of blood between the skull and the dura mater (outermost meningeal layer). This CT image shows a biconvex, hyperdense lesion confined to the epidural space, characteristic of an EDH.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Patients often experience a lucid interval: a transient recovery of consciousness after the initial trauma, followed by neurological deterioration.
  • Symptoms include headache, confusion, drowsiness, focal neurological deficits, and worsening intracranial pressure.

Management:

  • Requires urgent neurosurgical intervention to evacuate the hematoma.
  • Ligation or cauterization of the damaged meningeal artery is often necessary.

A. Acute subdural hematoma following head trauma

  • Subdural hematomas appear as crescent-shaped collections of blood, caused by tearing of bridging veins.
  • Radiographic characteristics differ from the lenticular shape of an epidural hematoma.

B. Chronic subdural hematoma following head trauma

  • Develops gradually over weeks to months, often after minor injuries.
  • Symptoms include headache, cognitive decline, and focal deficits. Radiographic appearance is typically crescentic.

D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

  • CT Findings: Blood in the subarachnoid space, often seen in the sulci and basal cisterns.
  • Associated with severe headache ("thunderclap headache"), photophobia, and meningeal signs (e.g., neck stiffness).

Key Takeaways

  • Acute epidural hematomas are characterized by a biconvex hyperdense lesion on CT, most commonly caused by middle meningeal artery rupture.
  • Differentiating features:
    • Epidural hematoma: Biconvex shape.
    • Subdural hematoma: Crescent shape.
    • Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Blood in the subarachnoid space.
  • Requires emergency intervention to prevent neurological deterioration.

Tags:

Topic Name: Traumatic brain injury:EDH

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 3457

choices.text: Immunologic phenomena: Osler's nodes, Roth's spots, glomerulonephritis
Vascular phenomena: Janeway lesions, arterial emboli, mycotic aneurysms
Positive echocardiographic findings of a valvular mass
Predisposition: predisposing heart condition or injection drug use

questions.text: Which of the following is not a minor diagnostic criterion for diagnosing the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a gross pathological specimen of a heart with infective endocarditis. Arrows point to large, friable, and irregular masses on the heart valves. These vegetations are composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms, often typical of infective endocarditis.

Commonly affected valves are the mitral and aortic valves in left-sided endocarditis, and the tricuspid valve in intravenous drug users with right-sided endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis typically results from bacteremia involving organisms like Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus viridans, or HACEK organisms, which adhere to damaged endocardium or prosthetic material

The Modified Duke Criteria is used to confirm the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. The vegetations seen in this image are strong evidence of endocardial involvement, which is a major criterion in the Duke Criteria

A. Immunologic phenomena: Osler's nodes, Roth's spots, glomerulonephritis

  • Minor Criterion: These are considered minor criteria in the Modified Duke Criteria.
  • Reflect immune-mediated damage caused by circulating immune complexes during infective endocarditis.

B. Vascular phenomena: Janeway lesions, arterial emboli, mycotic aneurysms

  • Minor Criterion: Vascular phenomena, such as painless Janeway lesions or complications like emboli and aneurysms, indicate embolic events due to vegetation fragments breaking off and lodging in distant vessels.

C. Positive echocardiographic findings of a valvular mass

  • Not a Minor Criterion: This is a major criterion under the Duke Criteria.
  • Positive echocardiography findings, such as a valvular mass, abscess, or new prosthetic valve dehiscence, strongly suggest endocardial involvement.

D. Predisposition: predisposing heart condition or injection drug use

  • Minor Criterion: History of heart valve disease, prosthetic valves, or injection drug use increases the risk of infective endocarditis and is included as a minor diagnostic criterion.

Key Takeaways

  • Minor criteria include factors like fever, vascular and immunologic phenomena, predisposing conditions, and nonspecific blood culture findings.
  • Positive echocardiographic findings (e.g., vegetations or abscesses) are classified as major criteria and not minor.

Tags:

Topic Name: Community acquired infections:Infective endocarditis

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 1026

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fishy vaginal odor and thin, homogenous white discharge. On examination, vaginal pH is found to be 5.5, and clue cells are observed on a wet mount. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a wet mount microscopy of vaginal fluid from a woman with bacterial vaginosis (BV).

Clue Cells:

  • Vaginal epithelial cells with obscured cell margins due to adherence of numerous coccobacillary organisms (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus species).
  • These cells have a characteristic granular appearance, which makes their edges indistinct under the microscope.
  • A predominance of bacterial overgrowth in the background.
  • Reduced presence of lactobacilli, which are normally part of the healthy vaginal flora.

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV)

Definition: BV is a vaginal condition caused by an imbalance in the normal vaginal flora, with a decrease in Lactobacillus species and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria like Gardnerella vaginalis and Mobiluncus.

Clinical Features:

  • Fishy vaginal odor (especially after intercourse).
  • Homogeneous, thin, white-gray vaginal discharge.
  • Vaginal pH >4.5.

Diagnosis: Amsel Criteria: Requires 3 out of 4:

  • Homogeneous discharge.
  • pH >4.5.
  • Positive "whiff test" (fishy odor with 10% KOH).
  • Clue cells on wet mount (vaginal epithelial cells with obscured margins due to bacterial adherence).

Complications:

  • Increased risk of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), preterm labor, and acquisition of STIs (e.g., HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia).

Treatment:

  • First-line: Oral metronidazole (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).
  • Alternatives: Intravaginal clindamycin cream or metronidazole gel.
  • Recurrent BV: Suppressive therapy with intravaginal metronidazole gel or probiotics (Lactobacillus crispatus).

A. Oral fluconazole

  • Fluconazole is the treatment of choice for vulvovaginal candidiasis (fungal infection), characterized by thick, curdy, white discharge and vaginal itching. It is not effective for bacterial vaginosis (BV), which is caused by overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria like Gardnerella vaginalis and Mobiluncus.

B. Intravaginal clindamycin

  • Intravaginal clindamycin is an FDA-approved treatment for bacterial vaginosis. BV is characterized by fishy odor, thin white discharge, and clue cells. Clindamycin cream effectively reduces anaerobic bacterial overgrowth without significant systemic side effects.

C. Oral azithromycin

  • Azithromycin is the treatment of choice for chlamydial infections, often associated with mucopurulent cervicitis. It does not target the anaerobic bacteria responsible for BV.

D. Vaginal boric acid suppositories

  • Boric acid is used for recurrent or refractory vulvovaginal candidiasis, not BV. It helps to restore vaginal pH but does not address the overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria.

Key Takeaway

  • BV is diagnosed clinically (homogeneous discharge, pH >4.5, clue cells, fishy odor) or with the Amsel criteria.
  • Effective treatments include oral metronidazole or intravaginal clindamycin.
  • Other options (e.g., fluconazole, azithromycin, boric acid) are used for different conditions and are not effective for BV.

Tags:

Topic Name: Infections:Bacterial Vaginosis

Difficulty level: Good to know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's, 21st edition, principles of internal medicine, page number 1085

questions.text: A 30 year old female was brought to hospital with complaints of weight loss, Anorexia, paresthesia and recurrent glossitis. CBC shows low Hb(7 g) and Increased MCV (105 fL). Perpheral smear(A) and Bone marrow(B) in image shown below. What could be the cause of this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
The images shows:

Peripheral Blood Smear (A):

  • Presence of macrocytic red blood cells (RBCs) with anisocytosis (variation in size) and poikilocytosis (variation in shape).
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils (more than 5 lobes in their nuclei), a hallmark of megaloblastic anemia.

Bone Marrow Smear (B):

  • Megaloblastic changes in erythroid precursors: Enlarged, abnormal erythroid precursors with an increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, nuclear asynchrony (nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation).
  • Presence of giant band forms and metamyelocytes in granulocyte precursors.
  • Dysplastic features in myeloid and erythroid precursors due to ineffective hematopoiesis.

Option D. Megaloblastic Anemia

  • Cause:
    • Caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate, leading to defective DNA synthesis and impaired cell division.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Weight loss, anorexia, paresthesia (neurological symptoms) due to B12 deficiency.
    • Recurrent glossitis (beefy red tongue) from impaired epithelial turnover.
    • Pancytopenia: Anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia from ineffective hematopoiesis.
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Macrocytic anemia: Low hemoglobin, increased MCV (>100 fL).
    • Hypersegmented neutrophils in peripheral smear.
    • Bone marrow shows megaloblastic changes.
  • Key Hallmarks:
    • Peripheral smear: Hypersegmented neutrophils and macrocytic RBCs.
    • Bone marrow: Megaloblastic maturation.

Option A. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):

    • Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with a predominance of myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophilia.
    • Does not typically show macrocytic RBCs or hypersegmented neutrophils.
    • Bone marrow reveals hypercellularity with myeloid hyperplasia. The clinical presentation (neurological symptoms, macrocytic anemia) and bone marrow findings are not consistent with CML.

Option B. Thalassemia:

    • Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic RBCs, target cells, and basophilic stippling. Normal or low MCV (<80 fL), not macrocytic.
    • The patient has macrocytic anemia, not microcytic, and no features of hemoglobinopathy such as target cells or basophilic stippling.

Option C. Hereditary Spherocytosis:

    • Peripheral smear shows spherocytes (small, round RBCs without central pallor).
    • Typically normocytic or slightly microcytic anemia with increased reticulocyte count.
    • Associated with jaundice, splenomegaly, and increased osmotic fragility.
    • The smear does not show spherocytes, and macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils is not a feature of hereditary spherocytosis.

Key Takeaway

  • The combination of macrocytic anemia, hypersegmented neutrophils, and megaloblastic bone marrow changes in a patient with neurological symptoms and glossitis strongly points to megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency. Other options lack the key findings seen in this case

Tags:

Topic Name: Hematology:Megaloblastic anemia

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page number 770

questions.text: Which of the following HRCT Thorax finding is not commonly present in the Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image illustrates a high-resolution CT (HRCT) scan of the thorax showing features characteristic of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF):

Option A. Honeycombing: Visible as small cystic spaces (typically <1 cm in diameter) stacked in multiple layers near the pleural surfaces, characteristic of advanced fibrosis.

Option B. Traction Bronchiectasis: Enlarged airways due to surrounding fibrotic lung pulling on the bronchi, further confirming the fibrotic process.

Option C. Subpleural Reticulation: Fine reticular lines predominantly located in the peripheral (subpleural) regions of the lungs, with a basal distribution.

Option D. Absence of Ground-Glass Opacities: Ground-glass opacities (diffuse hazy opacification) are not prominent in IPF and their presence often raises suspicion for other interstitial lung diseases, such as Nonspecific Interstitial Pneumonia (NSIP).

Nonspecific Interstitial Pneumonia (NSIP).

Key Takeaways:

  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF):
    • Most common interstitial lung disease of unknown cause.
    • Presents with progressive dyspnea and nonproductive cough.
    • Poor prognosis with median survival of 3-5 years.
  • Nonspecific Interstitial Pneumonia (NSIP):
    • Symmetric ground-glass opacities are common.

Affects younger, nonsmoking females and often associated with connective tissue diseases.

Tags:

Topic Name: Respiratory disease:ILD

Difficulty level: May know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page number 2193

questions.text: Identify the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows a pattern consistent with Third-Degree Atrioventricular (AV) Block (Complete Heart Block).

Option D.Third-Degree AV Block

  • Complete AV Dissociation: There is no relationship between P waves (atrium) and QRS complexes (ventricles). The atria and ventricles beat
  • Regular P-P Intervals and R-R Intervals: The P waves occur at a regular interval (sinus rhythm). The QRS complexes also occur at a regular interval but are completely independent of the P waves.
  • Escape Rhythm: The QRS complexes are either narrow (junctional escape rhythm) or wide (ventricular escape rhythm), depending on the origin of the escape rhythm.
  • Atrioventricular Block: Failure of atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles.

Option A. First-Degree AV Block:

  • Features:
    • Prolonged PR interval (>200 ms).
    • All P waves are followed by QRS complexes.
    • In this ECG, P waves are not conducted to QRS complexes, which excludes first-degree AV block.

Option B. Mobitz Type I Block (Wenckebach):

    • Progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted.
    • Typically associated with grouped beating (e.g., 2:1 or 3:1 conduction).
    • There is no progressive prolongation of PR intervals, and the block is complete in this ECG.

Option C. Mobitz Type II Block:

    • Fixed PR interval with intermittent dropped QRS complexes.
    • High risk of progression to complete heart block.
    • There is no fixed PR interval, and there is complete AV dissociation in the ECG.

Key Takeaway

  • Third-Degree AV Block is diagnosed when there is complete dissociation between atrial and ventricular activity, with regular P-P and R-R intervals and no conduction of atrial impulses to the ventricles. This ECG is consistent with a complete heart block.

Topic Name: CVS:A-V Block

Difficulty level: Must know

PYQ: NEET PG based

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page number 1882
